raw.description: Race of the respondent (hispanic, black or white)
raw.name: race

raw.description: Sex of the respondent (male or female)
raw.name: sex

raw.description: A boolean variable that equals 1 if the respondent was jailed between 1985 to 1994
raw.name: ever_jailed

raw.description: A composite variable creating by summing five wealth variables from the NLS data for the year 1985
raw.name: composite_wealth_1985

raw.description: A composite variable creating by summing five wealth variables from the NLS data for the year 1990
raw.name: composite_wealth_1990

raw.description: A composite variable creating by summing five wealth variables from the NLS data for the year 1996
raw.name: composite_wealth_1996

datasets.description: This dataset was created from the National Longitudinal Study of Youth's 1979 cohort to about the race, wealth, and incarceration status of the participants.
datasets.name: nls_incarceration_processed.csv

queries.question: Is the wealth of extremely poor people (10th percentile) not affected by factors like demographics, criminal history etc. compared to the people at higher spectrum of wealth?
How does the impact of race, gender, and incarceration status on wealth compare at different percentiles of the wealth distribution?
At what percentile (of the order of 10), the impact of race, gender, and incarceration status is insignificant on wealth?
What factors at the lowest end of the wealth distribution (10th percentile) do not significantly impact wealth when compared to higher ends of the wealth distribution (60th & 90th percentile)?
What is the effect between the race, gender, and incarceration status on wealth at the lowest end of the wealth distribution (10th percentile)?
What is the effect between the race, gender, and incarceration status on wealth at the highest end of the wealth distribution (90th percentile)?
